reviewText: Invisible Agent, 1942 filmThe story begins on a street. Four men enter a print shop and talk to Frank Griffin. They want to buy his grandfather's secret formula. Or else! They use force to make him talk. He talks. There is a struggle and he escapes to talk to the authorities. Then war begins. Mr. Raymond talks to Governement Officials about becoming an Invisible Agent. He will be dropped by parachute over Berlin to make contact with a man. "Surround the barn!" They only find clothes. "You are crazy!" Agent Raymond orders a coffin, "Empire style". The carpenter gives him the address of a contact, but he needs a taxi to meet this woman. "Mind if I smoke?" A Nazi official visits her with food from occupied countries. A bodyguard will protect Maria. He boasts about his influence to her."Poor darling!" "I really don't understand." Maria doesn't like her treatment. Cold cream makes Frank visible. Frank naps. Later the Gestapo man tells what happened to him. They return to Maria's room to question her. There is personal conflict between two men. The next morning Frank goes to Gestapo headquarters. Is this a trap? Mr. Stauffer talks to Frank, he wants the drug of invisibility. Frank doesn't have it, but he starts a fire as a distraction. "Don't let him get away!" But Frank does and returns to the coffin shop. The Baron visits Stauffer to ask about the book of spies. We see Heiser in prison awaiting execution. Frank analyzes his situation and offers him freedom if he tells about the plans to attack America. He does. Frank attacks the men who enter Heiser's prison cell. Frank and Heiser leave the prison and take a car. Schmidt isn't in his sho[. Will Frank be caught in a trap?Men carry a coffin out of the shop. Maria and Frank are captured! Heiser warns Stauffer about what happened. The Japanese captured Frank and Maria and keep them in their embassy. Nazi troops arrive and enter this embassy. Failure is not an option for the Baron and Stauffer. Frank drives Maria to the airport where they board a plane and take off for England. On the way they drop their load of bombs. "Thank goodness for the clouds." One Nazi official shows Heiser his Thompson machine gun. The British detect their airplane and open fire on it. They bail out before their plane crashes. There is a reunion in the hospital between Frank and Maria. The invisibility drug has worn off! There is a happy ending.Albert Basserman acted in Hitchcock's "Foreign Correspondent". He was a refugee from Nazi Germany (like Helmuth Dantine). I appreciate the intentions of this film, but its not a good story. It is sort of like those action serials used to attract customers. Yes, it is a dramatic comedy. Would it be better with Larry, Moe, and Curly? [The story of an invisible man may be a parody or critique of Adam Smith's "invisible hand" that regulated economic life. It shows what a real invisible man can do with his invisible hand.]
summary: How an Invisible Man Became a Spy

reviewText: I'm a big fan of all the old Universal movies and have collected most of them.I don't understand the negative comments! No it's not the Invisible Man orInvisible Revenge but it's better than the Invisible Woman! I like the Nazispy war theme mixed with the horror mystery of the invisible man. It's wellwritten and directed. Ilona Massey is gorgeous and graceful as ever! PeterLorre and Sir Hardwicke are great as evil Nazis! If your a fan of Invisible Manand Film Noir movies this is a great mix of both! Love it.
summary: Great Universal Horror/Film Noir Nazi Movie!

reviewText: The Invisible Agent is one hour and twenty-one minutes and was released on July 31, 1942. The main plot of this move is the grandson of Frank Griffin has inherited the formula of invisibility and has changed his name to hide his identity. Germen and Japanese agents have entered his shop to persuade Frank to hand over the formula, he escapes however. When Pearl Harbor is bombed Frank goes to work of the United States as an invisible agent. The Invisible Agent makes a few mistakes. When Frank Raymond (played by Jon Hall) is confronted is his shop by German and Japanese spies and revealed he is the grandson of Frank Griffin; says that Frank Griffin was shot down a killed. First that was Jack Griffin in the original Invisible Man and two Frank Griffin is a bachelor in the Invisible Man Returns. Some other trivia also is Jon Hall is the only person to play the Invisible Man in two films. Also Cedric Hardwicke starred in the Invisible Man Returns as well as this movie. The Invisible Agent is part comedy, part propaganda, and part suspense movie. Jon Hall is shown more then the Invisible Man and the Invisible Man Returns put together. The special effects are okay well. I just thought the script was weak and did not live up to the past three invisible movies. The Invisible Agent gets a C from me.
summary: Not as good as past invisible movies
Title: N/A

reviewText: Here we have yet another installment in the 'Invisible Man' series. This one coming between 'The Invisible Woman' and 'The Invisible Man's Revenge'. This film is interesting if your interested in the history of films and especially films made during World War II. The Propaganda is heavy and laughable in this strange but watch-able film. Like all the 'Invisible Man' movies, it's loosely tied to the other films in the series but, you don't have to watch them in any order or all of them to follow the story line of any one of them. The great cast includes Cedric Hardwicke, Peter Lorre, Jon Hall and Ilona Massey. Look closely to see Keye Luke from the Kung Fu TV show as the Japanese surgeon. This is available on DVD on the 'Invisible Man' Legacy Collection along with all four of the other Invisible Man movies from Universal. The DVD transfers are very good and there are some very good extras on the set.
summary: A DASH OF UNIVERSAL... A CUP OF WAR PROPAGANDA... AND A PINCH OF H.G. WELLS!

reviewText: The Invisible Agent is a war picture with a little bit of science fiction mixed it.  The drama is about the grandson of the original invisible man, who changes his name and thinks he will hide out running a paper shop for the rest of his life but nooooo.....  Cedric HardwickeThings to Come/Journey to the Center of Timeis the Nazi spy who roughens him up and Peter LorreMr. Moto Collection, Vol. 1 (Mr. Moto Takes A Chance / Mysterious Mr. Moto / Thank You Mr. Moto / Think Fast Mr. Moto) (4DVD)is the sadistic Japanese spy (like your Mr. Moto dark and sadistic?), which fires up Frank (played sarcastically by Jon HallHell Ship Mutiny).This is mid 1942 and the European and Pacific fronts are hot and heavy for Americans, so I would expect the Nazis to look like a bunch of dummies, but these actors talk like Noo Yawkas in overcoats.  The script is average wartime spy fare, and the effects are average even for the time period.  Interesting spy movie for the WWII fan, but for spooky adventure, not really.
